did.unittitle: Chris Coenen Collection on General Tom Thumb

physdesc.extent: 13 oversize boxes; 4 rolled item boxes/tubes; 3 card boxes; 2 half letter size document boxes; 2 framed items; 1 letter size document box; 1 legal size document box; 1 oversize flat file; 1 stereoscope.

did.abstract: This collection contains material related to P. T. Barnum and General Tom Thumb collected by Christopher Coenen, including artifacts, cabinet cards, cartes-de-visite, printed ephemera, printed materials, photographs, and stereographs.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Christopher Coenen A'71, 2018 and 2021, accession numbers MS-2019-048 and MS-2022-009.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Books related to P. T. Barnum and General Tom Thumb were not accessioned.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in six series: , Artifacts, Cabinet cards, Cartes-de-visite, Printed ephemera, Printed materials, and Stereographs.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Christopher Joseph Coenen attended Tufts from 1967 to 1971 and graduated from the Tufts University School of Arts, Sciences, and Engineering with a B.S. degree. Majoring in biology, he was a frequent visitor to Barnum Hall and Jumbo, the stuffed hide of an elephant donated by P. T. Barnum. In 1968, Dr. Russell Carpenter, a professor of biology and curator of Barnum Hall, gave a closing lecture on Barnum and Jumbo to his freshman zoology class. Upon graduation and completing research in the Bahamas the following year, Coenen entered the teaching profession. He taught for 42 years at the Berkshire School and Franklin Academy. Coenen's interest in antique photographs eventually led him to collect material related to Charles Stratton (General Tom Thumb). Coenen retired from teaching and resides in western Massachusetts.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Chris Coenen Collection on General Tom Thumb, 1750 -- 2010. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing of the 2018 accession was completed by Leah Edelman in 2019. Materials were placed in archival boxes, and loose materials were placed in folders where needed. Materials were arranged in one series with chronological order. A file and item-level inventory and series-level description were created, and the finding aid was also created at the time of processing. Further processing of the 2021 accession was completed by Records and Accessioning Archivist, Jane Kelly, in 2021. Materials were placed in archival boxes, and item-level description was created using a donor-provided inventory. Series-level descriptions were created, and the finding aid was updated at the time of processing. Material from the 2018 accession was integrated into the series created during processing in 2021.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Collection on P. T. Barnum, 1818 -- 2009. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains material related to P. T. Barnum and General Tom Thumb collected by Christopher Coenen. The collection contains artifacts, including ceramic plates, paper dolls, a board game, coins, autographs, and slides; cabinet cards; cartes-de-visite; printed ephemera and printed materials, including clippings, copies of daguerreotypes and lithographs, advertisements, fliers, sheet music, brochures, and booklets; and stereographs. Item-level description was provided by the donor and has not been verified.

scopecontent.head: Content Warning
scopecontent.p: This finding aid contains language that may be offensive or outdated. Because such language is in direct transcription of materials or donor-supplied metadata, it has not yet been reviewed or changed. Keeping this language intact can potentially tell us important things about bigotry and bias in a particular historical context. It can also preserve terms formerly applied by a group to self-identify that have since fallen out of common usage.

More specifically, this collection contains ableist images and language, particularly related to dwarfism, racist imagery including blackface, and materials related to phrenology. For more information on DCA's content warning policy please visit our website.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Any intellectual property rights that the donor possesses have been transferred to Tufts University.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Charles Sherwood Stratton, better known by his stage name "General Tom Thumb," was born January 4, 1838 in Bridgeport, Connecticut to Sherwood Edward Stratton and Cynthia Thompson. Stratton was an average sized baby at birth, but his growth slowed at around six months of age when he was approximately 25 inches tall. He eventually grew to 40 inches tall.

P. T. Barnum heard of Stratton and contacted his parents. Stratton's parents agreed to allow their four-year-old son to perform and be on display at Barnum's American Museum in New York City in 1842. At the age of five, Stratton was taken on tour across the United States, singing, dancing, and impersonating characters such as Cupid and Napoleon Bonaparte. In 1844, Barnum took Stratton to perform in England and France, including two performances for Queen Victoria. Stratton returned to the United States after the three-year tour and continued to perform for American audiences as part of an exhibit of "human curiosities."

In 1863, Stratton married Lavinia Warren, who was also a little person who he met while working at Barnum's American Museum. The wedding took place at Grace Episcopal Church in New York City and was widely covered in the media. George Washington Morrison Nutt, known by his stage name "Commodore Nutt," was the best man, and Warren's sister Minnie Warren was a bridesmaid. Approximately 10,000 guests attended the wedding reception. Stratton and Warren were received by President Abraham Lincoln at the White House after their wedding and then traveled to Europe and what is today Bangladesh.
Stratton continued to perform until 1878. He died of a stroke in Middleboro, Massachusetts on July 15, 1883. He was buried in Mountain Grove Cemetery in Bridgeport, Connecticut.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Phineas Taylor (P. T.) Barnum (1810 - 1891), was a showman and circus entrepreneur who also served on the board of Trustees of Tufts College and as a benefactor of the institution in its early years.

Barnum was born in Bethel, Connecticut on July 5, 1810, to Philo F. Barnum, a farmer and shopkeeper, and Irena Taylor. He held many jobs as a youth, including herding cattle, selling theater tickets, and publishing the abolitionist newspaper The Herald of Freedom (1831-1834). Barnum married seamstress Charity Hallett in 1829, and they had four daughters.

In 1835 Barnum purchased the right to exhibit the elderly enslaved woman Joice Heth, as the supposed 161-year-old nurse of George Washington, at Niblo's Gardens in New York City. He then led a small traveling circus through the South and West, and engaged in a number of unsuccessful business ventures. In 1841 Barnum bought and re-opened the American Museum in New York City. Exhibits included the Feegee [sic] mermaid, the bearded lady, and the "Egress," along with fossils and natural history specimens. Barnum's half-brother Philo introduced him to the dwarf Charles Sherwood Stratton in 1842, and Barnum hired Stratton as an exhibit under the name General Tom Thumb. Barnum and Stratton made several tours to England and Europe (1844, 1858).

From 1851 to 1857 Barnum was one of the founding trustees of the new Universalist institution, Tufts College (founded in 1852 and opened to students in 1854). After being elected to the Trustees in 1851, Barnum resigned in 1857, because his busy schedule of tours precluded his attendance at board meetings. Between 1882 and 1884, Barnum anonymously gave over $50,000 to Tufts College to build the Barnum Museum of Natural History. He also left over $30,000 in his will to build two subsequent wings. In 1889, Barnum donated the mounted skin of Jumbo the elephant to the Barnum Museum at Tufts. Barnum hoped that the publicity might be useful to the college, and Jumbo became the school mascot.

In the 1870s Barnum organized the "Greatest Show on Earth," which traveled by train through the United States and Canada. In 1881 he joined his business rivals to form the Barnum and Bailey Circus. He died in Bridgeport, Connecticut on April 7, 1891.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Lavinia Warren Stratton was born Mercy Lavinia Bump on October 31, 1842 in Middleborough, Massachusetts, to Huldah Pierce Warren and James Sullivan Bump. Lavinia, as well as her sister Minnie, had a form of dwarfism.

Warren began teaching at the age of 16 and later took a job singing and dancing on a Mississippi showboat owned by a cousin. The program, "The Museum of Living Wonders," billed her as the "Lilliputian Queen." Warren danced, sang show tunes, and occasionally performed a double act with a woman with gigantism, Silvia Hardy, from Maine. In 1862, P. T. Barnum met Warren and invited her to work at the American Museum in New York City.

In 1863, Warren married Charles Stratton, known as General Tom Thumb, who was also a little person whom she met while working at Barnum's American Museum. The wedding took place at Grace Episcopal Church in New York City and was widely covered in the media. George Washington Morrison Nutt, known by his stage name "Commodore Nutt," was the best man, and Warren's sister Minnie Warren was a bridesmaid. Approximately 10,000 guests attended the wedding reception. Warren and Stratton were received by President Abraham Lincoln at the White House after their wedding and then traveled to Europe and what is today Bangladesh.

After Stratton's death, Warren married Count Primo Magri. They operated a roadside stand in Middleborough, Massachusetts that featured other little people. Warren appeared alongside Magri in a 1915 silent film, "The Lilliputian's Courtship."
Warren died on November 25, 1919 and was buried next to Stratton in Mountain Grove Cemetery in Bridgeport, Connecticut.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Count Primo Magri, also known as Count Rosebud, was born in Italy in 1840. Magri came to the United States in 1878. He married Lavinia Warren Stratton in 1885. They operated a roadside stand in Middleborough, Massachusetts that featured other little people. Magri appeared with Warren in a 1915 silent film, "The Lilliputian's Courtship." He died in Middleborough, Massachusetts in 1920.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Huldah Pierce Warren Bump, better known as Minnie Warren, was born June 2, 1849 in Middleborough, Massachusetts to Huldah Pierce Warren and James Sullivan Bump. Minnie, as well as her sister Lavinia, had a form of dwarfism. Warren performed as a singer and was married to Edmund Newell, a little person who was also a paid performer for P. T. Barnum. Warren died on July 23, 1878 due to complications from childbirth. She is buried in Nemasket Hill Cemetery in Middleborough, Massachusetts.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: George Washington Morrison Nutt, best known by his stage name Commodore Nutt, was born in Manchester, New Hampshire to Major Rodnia Nutt and Maria Nutt. Nutt was a little person who performed in circuses and was hired by P. T. Barnum to appear in the American Museum in New York City. Nutt performed internationally with General Tom Thumb, Lavinia Warren, and Minnie Warren from 1869 to 1872. Upon returning from touring, Nutt ceased working for Barnum. He toured with a comic opera company, organized a variety show on the west coast of the United States, and ran saloons in Oregon and California.
In 1879, Nutt married Lilian Elston of Redwood City, California. He returned to New York City and died of Bright's disease, a historical classification of kidney disease, in May 1881.

did.unittitle: Artifacts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains artifacts related to Tom Thumb, including slides, prints, autographs, paper dolls, ceramic plates, medals, souvenir charms, cards, a board game, a doll, and a hack saw frame.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in received order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains cabinet cards related to Tom Thumb. Cabinet cards are a type of photograph that is typically mounted on a card. They were most popular in the 1880s and 1890s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in received order.

did.unittitle: Cartes-de-visite

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains cartes-de-visite related to Tom Thumb, including images of Charles Stratton, Lavinia Warren, Commodore Nutt, Minnie Warren, Count Primo Magri, Ernesto Magri, P. T. Barnum, Jennie Quigley, Sarah and Lucy Adams, and Zoe Meleke. The carte-de-visite is a type of small photograph that was often traded among friends in the late 19th century.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in received order.

did.unittitle: Printed ephemera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains printed ephemera related to Tom Thumb, including postcards, advertisements, lithographs, prints, fliers, event programs, clippings, and engravings. Subjects of these materials include Tom Thumb, Lavinia Warren, Count Primo Magri, Ernesto Magri, Tom Thumb's carriage and wedding, the Tom Thumb Show and other performances, and Tom Thumb and Lavinia Warren's activities and travels.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in received order.

did.unittitle: General Tom Thumb print
Jumbo photographs, cards, and prints

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains two photographs of Jumbo in Barnum Hall and one photograph of the fire at Barnum Hall in 1975; a print titled "Jumbo at work and play;" and cards of Jumbo in various scenes.

did.unittitle: Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus program
The World of Phineas T. Barnum photograph portfolio

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains a portfolio of print reproductions of portrait photographs originally taken by Matthew Brady of members of Barnum's troupe, including dancer Ernestine de Faiber, General Tom Thumb and his wife Lavinia Warren Bumpus, James Murphy (the "Irish Giant"), Anna Swan (the "Nova Scotia Giantess"), Jane Campbell (the "Fat Lady"), Isaac Sprague (the "Living Skeleton"), Mrs. Myers (first name unknown, the "Bearded Lady"), and Siamese twins Chang and Eng.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains printed materials related to Tom Thumb, including sheet music, advertisements, magazines, clippings, brochures, and booklets. Subjects of these materials include Tom Thumb, Lavinia Warren, phrenology, and P. T. Barnum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains printed copies of scans created by the donor. The majority of the material in the collection was scanned.

did.unittitle: Stereographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains stereographs related to Tom Thumb. Stereographs are two nearly identical photographs displayed side by side and meant to be viewed with a stereoscope. When viewed through the stereoscope, the stereographs appear three-dimensional. Subjects of these stereographs include Tom Thumb, the Barnum Museum, Lavinia Warren, Count Primo Magri, Ernesto Magri, Commodore Nutt, and Tom Thumb and Lavinia Warren's wedding.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in received order.

did.unittitle: Charles Stratton and Lavinia Warren's House, Middleboro, Mass.; Tom Thumb out front

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tom is posed with a dog outside the house. The home was built Ca. 1870 while they were on their world tour.; the dimensions were altered to suit their needs- lower window frames, shorter stair treads, etc.; home is owned privately in Middleboro across from the Bump homestead
